Title: The Effects of a Tier 3 Intervention on the Mathematics Performance of Second Grade Students With Severe Mathematics Difficulties
Authors: Brian R. Bryant; Diane Pedrotty Bryant; Jennifer Porterfield; Minyi Shih Dennis; Terry Falcomata; Courtney Valentine; Chelsea Brewer; Kathy Bell
Summary: The study examined the effectiveness of a systematic, explicit, and intensive Tier 3 intervention on the mathematics performance of second-grade students with severe mathematics difficulties. The intervention focused on improving students' number and operations concepts and procedures, which are foundational for later mathematics success. The results showed significant improvements in mathematics performance for most students, allowing them to exit the Tier 3 intervention.

Title: THE EFFECTS OF TIER 2 INTER VENTION ON THE MATHEMA TICS PERFORMANCE OF FIRST -GRADE STUDENTS WHO ARE A T RISK FOR MATHEMA TICS DIFFICUL TIES
Authors: Diane Pedrotty Bryant; Brian R. Bryant; Russell M. Gersten; Nancy N. Scammacca; Catherine Funk; Amanda Winter; Minyi Shih; Cathy Pool
Summary: The article presents the results of a study that examined the effects of Tier 2 intervention on the performance of first-grade students who were identified as at risk for mathematics difficulties. The study found a significant intervention effect on the Texas Early Mathematics Inventories-Progress Monitoring (TEMI-PM) total standard score for the Tier 2 students who received 20-minute intervention booster lessons in number and operation skills and concepts for 23 weeks.

Title: The Development of Automatic Numerosity Processing in Preschoolers: Evidence for Numerosity–Perceptual Interference
Authors: Laurence Rousselle; Marie-Pascale Noël
Summary: This research examines the development of automatic processing of numerosity and perceptual information in preschoolers using a numerical Stroop paradigm. The results show that reciprocal influences between numerical and perceptual information exist from as early as age 3, and the sensitivity to irrelevant numerical cues tends to increase with age despite children's growing inhibition capacities. The study suggests that automatic numerosity processing starts to emerge earlier in development than previously thought.

Title: Performance Differences on a Measure of Mathematics Vocabulary for English Learners and Non-English Learners With and Without Mathematics Difficulty
Authors: Sarah R. Powell; Katherine A. Berry; Le M. Tran
Summary: The study examined the mathematics vocabulary performance of 3rd grade students, including English Learners (ELs) and non-ELs with and without mathematics difficulty (MD). Results showed that ELs scored lower than non-ELs across all groups, and both ELs and non-ELs with equation and word-problem difficulty demonstrated lower performance on the mathematics vocabulary measure than students with only equation or word-problem difficulty. The findings indicate that ELs and students with MD have limited mathematics vocabulary knowledge and may require focused instruction on the language of mathematics.

Title: Cognitive Strategies, Working Memory, and Growth in Word Problem Solving in Children With Math Difficulties
Authors: H. Lee Swanson; Catherine M. Lussier; Michael J. Orosco
Summary: This study investigated the role of strategy instruction and working memory capacity (WMC) on word problem solving accuracy in children with and without math difficulties (MD). The findings suggest that the availability of ample WM resources is an important precondition for strategy training to be successful for children with MD, as strategies are resource demanding and can easily overtax children with relatively smaller WMCs, leading to poorer learning outcomes. The study found that when WMC was set to a relatively high level, children with MD performed significantly better under visual-only strategy conditions, while children without MD performed better under verbal + visual conditions, compared to control conditions.

Title: Effects of Computer-Mediated Versus Teacher-Mediated Instruction on the Mathematical Word Problem-Solving Performance of Third-Grade Students With Mathematical Difficulties
Authors: Jayne M. Leh; Asha K. Jitendra
Summary: This study compared the effectiveness of computer-mediated instruction (CMI) and teacher-mediated instruction (TMI) on the word problem-solving performance of third-grade students struggling in mathematics. Both conditions integrated cognitive modeling that focused on the problem structure using visual representations. The results showed no statistically significant differences between the two conditions at posttest and on a 4-week retention test of word problem-solving. Furthermore, there was no transfer of the word problem-solving skills to a standardized mathematics achievement test.

Title: Effects of Computer-Mediated Versus Teacher-Mediated Instruction on the Mathematical Word Problem-Solving Performance of Third-Grade Students With Mathematical Difficulties
Authors: Jayne M. Leh; Asha K. Jitendra
Summary: This study compared the effectiveness of computer-mediated instruction and teacher-mediated instruction on the word problem-solving performance of students struggling in mathematics. Both conditions integrated cognitive modeling that focused on the problem structure using visual representations with critical instructional elements specifically targeting the needs of at-risk students. The results showed no statistically significant between-condition differences at posttest and on a 4-week retention test of word problem-solving, and no transfer of the word problem-solving skills to a standardized mathematics achievement test.

Title: The Effects of Strategic Counting Instruction, with and without Deliberate Practice, on Number Combination Skill among Students with Mathematics Difficulties
Authors: Lynn S. Fuchs; Sarah R. Powell; Pamela M. Seethaler; Paul T. Cirino; Jack M. Fletcher; Douglas Fuchs; Carol L. Hamlett
Summary: This study assessed the effects of strategic counting instruction, with and without deliberate practice, on number combination (NC) skill among students with mathematics difficulties (MD). The results showed that strategic counting without deliberate practice produced superior NC fluency compared to control, while strategic counting with deliberate practice effected superior NC fluency and transfer to procedural calculations compared to both competing conditions. The study also replicated the efficacy of the Pirate Math word-problem tutoring program.

Title: Solving Word Problems using Schemas: A Review of the Literature
Authors: Sarah R. Powell
Summary: This review highlights two schema approaches for 2nd- and 3rd-grade students at-risk for or with learning disabilities: schema-based instruction and schema-broadening instruction. A total of 12 schema studies were reviewed and synthesized. Both types of schema approaches enhanced the word-problem skill of students at-risk for or with learning disabilities. Based on the review, suggestions are provided for incorporating word-problem instruction using schemas.

Title: Early Numerical Competencies and Students with Mathematics Difficulty
Authors: Dr. Sarah R. Powell; Dr. Lynn S. Fuchs
Summary: This article describes important early numerical competencies, such as understanding of numbers, counting, number recognition, and basic mathematical concepts. It highlights the importance of these foundational skills for later mathematics achievement, and discusses the difficulties that some students face in developing these early numerical competencies. The article also provides recommendations for explicit, conceptual, and motivational instruction to help students who struggle with mathematics.

Title: Intensive Intervention for Students with Mathematics Disabilities: Seven Principles of Effective Practice
Authors: Lynn S. Fuchs; Douglas Fuchs; Sarah R. Powell; Pamela M. Seethaler; Paul T. Cirino; Jack M. Fletcher
Summary: The article focuses on intervention for third-grade students with serious mathematics deficits. It provides background on two key aspects of mathematical cognition - number combinations and story problems - that present major challenges for students in the primary grades. The article then describes seven principles of effective intervention for students with mathematics disabilities, using validated interventions as examples.

Title: The Effects of Dynamic Strategic Math on English Language Learners' Word Problem Solving
Authors: Michael J. Orosco; H. Lee Swanson; Rollanda O'Connor; Cathy Lussier
Summary: This study assessed the effectiveness of a math comprehension strategy called Dynamic Strategic Math (DSM) on word problem solving for Latino English language learners (ELLs). The DSM strategy provides performance-contingent feedback based on the student's reading and language comprehension level. The results suggest the intervention facilitated math problem-solving performance for the ELL participants.

Title: How bipedalism shapes humans' actions with hand tools
Authors: Dorothy M. Fragaszy; Damian G. Kelty-Stephen; Madhur Mangalam
Summary: This article explores the relationship between human bipedalism and the use of hand tools, a form of embodied cognition. It discusses how posture and body dynamics shape the perception of affordances and the dexterous use of objects. The authors use the metaphor of cascades to capture the dynamic, nonlinear transformations in morphology and behavior associated with posture and tool use across evolutionary and developmental timescales. The article also highlights the potential of multifractal cascade analysis to reveal the nonlinear, cross-scale interactions across the entire body that support the perception of affordances for actions with tools.

Title: Brains in sync, friends in empathy: interbrain neural mechanisms underlying the impact of interpersonal closeness on mutual empathy
Authors: Chennan Lin; Xinxin Lin; Weicheng Lian; Wenting Zhang; Weiwei Peng
Summary: This research explores the neural mechanisms underlying the impact of interpersonal closeness on mutual empathy. The study found that dyads of friends exhibited greater affect sharing than strangers when witnessing their partners being accepted or rejected, as evidenced by more pronounced event-related potential similarity and increased interbrain neural synchronization of brain alpha-oscillation between the empathizer's left prefrontal cortex and the target's left temporoparietal junction. These findings highlight the sensitivity of empathy to interpersonal closeness, linking it to sustained attention, detailed evaluation in social scenarios, and functional communication between brain regions for mentalizing and emotional regulation.

Title: Cortical Surface Area Profile Mediates Effects of Childhood Disadvantage on Later-Life General Cognitive Ability
Authors: Rongxiang Tang; Jeremy A. Elman; Chandra A. Reynolds; Olivia K. Puckett; Matthew S. Panizzon; Michael J. Lyons; Donald J Hagler Jr; Christine Fennema-Notestine; Lisa T. Eyler; Stephen M. Dorros; Anders M. Dale; William S. Kremen; Carol E. Franz
Summary: The study examined whether the cortical surface area (SA) profile, which reflects the spatial patterning of SA across the cortex, mediates the effects of childhood disadvantage on later-life general cognitive ability (GCA) in a sample of older adults. The results showed that around 1.31% of the effects of childhood disadvantage on later-life GCA were mediated by cortical SA profile, suggesting that childhood disadvantage may contribute to later-life GCA differences partly by influencing the spatial patterning of cortical SA in a way that deviates from the normative cortical organizational principle.

Title: The Role of Executive Function in the Co-occurrence of ADHD and Developmental Dyscalculia in Chinese Children
Authors: Jing Zhang; Min Dong; Lu Liu; Sunwei Qiu; Meirong Pan; Xinlin Zhou; Qiujin Qian
Summary: This study aimed to elucidate the characteristics of executive function deficits in children with Attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) comorbid with developmental dyscalculia (ADHD+DD). The results showed that both ADHD groups had more severe executive function impairment than the control group, and the ADHD+DD group performed worse in performance-based executive functions but similar in scale-based executive functions compared to the ADHD-DD group. Verbal working memory, processing speed, and working memory factors were identified as potential shared risk factors for ADHD and arithmetic ability, while cognitive flexibility and inhibition were found to have specific contributions to arithmetic ability. Processing speed and inhibition were also potential etiological elements for distinguishing ADHD-DD and ADHD+DD.

Title: Assessment of Knowledge of Learning Disabilities and Workshop for Palestinian Primary School Teachers: A Single-Center Study
Authors: Dr Nizar Marzouqa; Mr George Ibrahim; Ms Nora Marzouqa; Ms Alessia Grazia Morea
Summary: The study aimed to assess primary school teachers' knowledge of learning disabilities and design interactive lectures targeting revealed gaps. A survey was conducted, and a four-session workshop was held to provide knowledge and interactive activities on normal child development, learning disability types, specific learning disorders, developmental disorders, and multidisciplinary management. The results showed that teachers had an average overall score of 55% on the pre-assessment, with the highest section mean being developmental disorders. The feedback from the workshop was positive, with teachers reporting more confidence and enthusiasm to interact with students with learning and developmental disabilities.

Title: Experiences of medical students and doctors with dyslexia: A systematic review
Authors: Suhail Amin Tarafdar; Noha Seoudi; Ruoyin Luo; Kalman Winston
Summary: This systematic review explores the experiences of, and identifies strategies for, medical students and postgraduate doctors with dyslexia. The review found largely negative experiences, such as stigma, and that dyslexia can impact assessment performance, though reasonable adjustments are effective. Strategies to reduce difficulties include peer support, organizational inclusivity, and interactive educational methodologies. Dyslexia also impacts the career trajectory of doctors. The review recommends training programs promote an inclusive environment and provide reasonable adjustments, with flexible strategies according to individual needs.

Title: Developing an explainable machine learning and fog computing-based visual rating scale for the prediction of dementia progression
Authors: Zainab H. Ali; Esraa Hassan; Shimaa Elgamal; Nora El-Rashidy
Summary: This study introduces an innovative and reliable context-aware health monitoring system based on fog computing to measure mental impairment in the elderly population. The framework provides screening tests utilizing MMSE and MoCA to achieve accurate and real-time monitoring of cognitive function, allowing for early detection and treatment of mental disorders. The proposed machine learning model, using an ensemble AdaBoost approach, achieves high accuracy in predicting dementia progression compared to traditional MMSE and MoCA scores.

Title: Effects of digital interventions on neuroplasticity and brain function of individuals with developmental disabilities: A systematic review
Authors: Hyunyoung Lee; Yoomi Shin; Hayoung Moon; Yuna Choi; Anna Lee
Summary: This review examines the effects of digital interventions on neuroplasticity and neural functions of individuals with developmental disabilities. The results demonstrate that digital interventions using cognitive training, neuromodulation, and social cognitive training can enhance neural functions and neuroplasticity in this population. Further studies with diverse methodologies and a broader spectrum of developmental disabilities are needed to fully understand the potential of digital interventions in addressing neurodevelopmental challenges.

Title: Diversity in Education Study (DivES): Investigating a neurodiversity module in higher education
Authors: Amy J. Schwichtenberg; Katherine Mirah; Amy Janis; Moon West; Annabelle L. Atkin
Summary: This study explored the impact of a neurodiversity-focused module within a college classroom. The module was taught in an undergraduate course on diversity, and pre- and post-surveys were used to evaluate its impact on student understanding of neurodiversity, self-endorsements of a neurodivergent identity, and critical consciousness of ableism. The results showed that the module increased neurodiversity awareness and self-endorsements, but did not positively shift critical consciousness of ableism scores.

Title: Object but no room tilt illusion due to apperceptive visual agnosia in a right parieto-occipital lesion disconnecting visual–spatial integration
Authors: Philipp J. Koch; Tabea Kürten; Anja Fellbrick; Andreas Sprenger; Christoph Helmchen
Summary: The research article describes a case study of a patient with severe apperceptive visual agnosia and object tilt illusions, caused by a right-sided posterior reversible encephalopathy syndrome (PRES) affecting the primary and secondary visual cortex as well as the dorsal part of the superior parietal lobe, while sparing the multisensory vestibular brain areas. The patient experienced distortion of visual objects and 180° tilts of objects, but without room tilt illusion, suggesting a disconnection of visual-spatial integration.

Title: Natural Products for Drug Discovery in Cognitive Disabilities: Bibliometric Hotspots, Research Trends, Conceptual Framework, and Future Directions
Authors: Mohammed Albratty; Maryam Halawi; Ali Mufraih Albarrati
Summary: This study provides a bibliometric overview of the therapeutic potential of natural products in cognitive disabilities, highlighting growth patterns, themes, and future directions. It examines research focus, geographic trends, and collaboration, with Alzheimer's disease dominating the field alongside topics such as oxidative stress, neuroprotection, and molecular docking. Emerging trends include ferroptosis, UPLC-Q-TOF-MS, and network pharmacology, which have marked advancements in therapeutic and computational approaches.

Title: High-field fMRI at 7 Tesla reveals topographic responses tuned to number in the developing human brain
Authors: Ga-Ram Jeong; Joram Soch; Robert Trampel; Andreas Nieder; Michael A. Skeide
Summary: This study used high-field fMRI at 7 Tesla to investigate how the developing human brain represents numerosity. The researchers found that children aged 11-12 years already exhibit logarithmic Gaussian tuning and topographically organized responses to adjacent numerosities, similar to what has been observed in adults. Remarkably, the tuning models explained comparable amounts of variance in children and adults, indicating that the precision of number representation is already quite advanced in the developing brain.

Title: Tourette Syndrome: A Catalyst for Operationalizing Neurodiversity
Authors: Abraham Graber; Matthew Rizzo
Summary: This article introduces the neurodiversity paradigm, which considers some neurological conditions as diversity rather than simply disease. It discusses the implications of this paradigm for research and practice, including potential challenges from the anti-therapy sentiment within the Tourette syndrome community. The article aims to demonstrate that the neurodiversity paradigm is empirically tractable and chart a course for constructive and scientific investigation of its central claims in relation to neurology.

Title: Assessment of microstructural abnormalities in gray and white matter of minimal hepatic encephalopathy patients using diffusion kurtosis imaging and their associations with neurocognitive dysfunction
Authors: Qing Sun; Wenliang Fan; Yuan Liu; Zhifeng Kou; Ping Han
Summary: This study used diffusion kurtosis imaging (DKI) to assess microstructural abnormalities in both gray matter and white matter of patients with minimal hepatic encephalopathy (MHE). The results showed that MHE patients had decreased fractional anisotropy in the temporal part of the left superior longitudinal fasciculus and decreased kurtosis fractional anisotropy in the left corticospinal tract and anterior thalamic radiation, which correlated with worse neurocognitive test scores. MHE patients also exhibited increased volume of the thalamus. These findings suggest that disruption of microstructural integrity may underlie the pathophysiological underpinnings of neurocognitive dysfunction in MHE.

Title: Academic self-concept and reading comprehension among students with learning disabilities: Serial mediating effect of reading anxiety and reading motivation
Authors: Halime Miray Sümer Dodur; Mustafa Ceylan
Summary: This study investigates the relationship between academic self-concept and reading comprehension among middle school students with learning disabilities, focusing on the serial mediating roles of reading anxiety and reading motivation. The findings highlight the importance of addressing both reading anxiety and motivation to improve reading comprehension in students with learning disabilities. Enhancing academic self-concept and reducing reading anxiety can significantly boost reading motivation and comprehension skills.

Title: Individual Differences in Statistical Learning and Semantic Adaptation: An N400 Study
Authors: Márton Munding; Bálint Forgács; Krisztina Sára Lukics; Ágnes Lukács
Summary: This study examined the relationship between individual differences in statistical learning (SL) abilities and the N400 event-related potential, which is associated with semantic processing during language comprehension. The results showed that better online SL performance was associated with larger N400 amplitudes across different levels of cloze probability. Working memory also interacted with SL in modulating N400 amplitude. These findings suggest that individual differences in SL abilities contribute to variability in the N400 response, supporting the view that semantic operations reflected by the N400 may involve statistical learning processes.

Title: Challenges in disability certification in psychiatry in India
Authors: Apoorva K. Bachhav; Harshit B. Sharma; Kartik M. Singhai
Summary: This viewpoint draws attention to the disparities that exist between the Rights of Persons with Disabilities Act, 2016 and the facilities that are available to specialists on the digital platform of certification for mental illnesses to address the severity of the impairment. It also recognizes that the lack of clear rules makes it difficult to reevaluate both single and multiple disabilities. The process of disability certification is further complicated by other factors, including inadequate training of medical professionals and clerical staff, server associated delays as well as the lack of uniformity of standard operating procedures among disability centers across the country.

Title: Exome analysis links kidney malformations to developmental disorders and reveals causal genes
Authors: Hila Milo Rasouly; Ali G. Gharavi
Summary: This study examines rare coding variants in CAKUT (congenital anomalies of the kidney and urinary tract) patients and controls, identifying diagnostic and candidate diagnostic variants in 14.1% of cases. The results suggest shared genetic mechanisms between CAKUT and other developmental disorders, with 18% of CAKUT patients having neurodevelopmental or cardiac phenotypes. The study identifies 40 candidate CAKUT genes, confirming ARID3A and NR6A1 as causal.

Title: Specificity, Co-Occurrence, and Growth: Math and Reading Skill Development in Children With Learning Disabilities
Authors: Katherine Helene Connors; Emily L. Guertin; Melissa Nichol; Joan M. Bosson-Heenan; Jeffrey R. Gruen; Jan C. Frijters
Summary: The study analyzes longitudinal patterns of growth, co-occurrence, and specificity in the math and reading skills of children with and without learning disabilities. The findings reveal that math and reading trajectories of children with learning disabilities parallel those of children without disabilities, with skill growth slowing over time. The impairment levels and growth trajectories of children with co-occurring disabilities match the within-domain patterns of children with isolated disabilities, supporting an additive model of co-occurrence. Math disability is domain-specific and becomes more pronounced over time, while reading disability impacts both domains early and maintains curriculum-contingent math deficits.

Title: The interaction effect of pedagogical agent and emotional feedback on effective learning: a 2 × 2 factorial experiment in online formative assessment
Authors: Xiaoqin Tang; Li Jiang; Guoli Liu; Hongxia Li
Summary: This study conducted a 2 × 2 experimental study using an online learning system to explore the effects of pedagogical agents and emotional feedback on learning performance during formative assessments. The results showed that pedagogical agents had a slightly negative influence on transfer scores, while emotional feedback significantly boosted engagement. When both were combined, learners exhibited the highest motivation, although this did not significantly enhance emotional perception or performance and slightly reduced transfer scores. The use of these tools also shortened learning duration.

Title: Leveraging and Harnessing Generative Artificial Intelligence to Mitigate the Burden of Neurodevelopmental Disorders (NDDs) in Children
Authors: Obinna Ositadimma Oleribe
Summary: The article explores the potential of Generative Artificial Intelligence (GenAI) in transforming the management of Neurodevelopmental Disorders (NDDs) in children. It discusses how GenAI can enhance screening, diagnosis, personalized treatment, research, and caregiver support for NDDs, which have a significant global impact on child health and development. The article calls for policy initiatives to integrate GenAI into NDD management systems to address the persistent challenges in early identification, accurate diagnosis, and effective treatment of these disorders.

Title: Distinct neural representational changes following cross-format number tutoring in children with mathematical difficulties
Authors: Yunji Park; Yuan Zhang; Flora Schwartz; Teresa Iuculano; Hyesang Chang; Vinod Menon
Summary: This study evaluated a 4-week personalized cross-format number (CFN) tutoring program designed to strengthen the symbolic-nonsymbolic mappings in children with mathematical difficulties (MD) aged 7-10 years. The CFN tutoring was associated with significant improvements in numerical and arithmetic fluency. Neural representational similarity (NRS) analysis revealed that deficient cross-format NRS in children with MD was normalized following tutoring, aligning with pre-tutoring levels of typically-developing (TD) peers. This normalization was most pronounced in parietal and parahippocampal regions known to support quantity and spatial representation. The study suggests that developmentally tailored interventions can support children with MD through targeted, evidence-based strategies.

Title: Summary Graphs Covary with Reading and Language Comprehension in School-age Children in the Spanish Language
Authors: Anabel Fernández-Blanco; Nancy Estévez-Pérez; Klency González Hernández
Summary: The study aimed to determine if there is an association between the topological properties of text summaries (represented as graphs) and traditional measures of reading and language comprehension in Cuban school-age children. Two correlational studies found that the density of the text summary graphs was significantly associated with reading comprehension in fifth graders and language comprehension in sixth graders, after controlling for other cognitive factors. The results suggest that graph theory analysis of text summaries could be a useful tool for assessing and characterizing reading and language comprehension.

Title: A Dotted Triangle or Dots of Three: The Role of Representational Content on Working Memory Capacity in Early Childhood
Authors: Tongyan Ren; Xuechen Ding; Chen Cheng
Summary: Children's working memory (WM) performance varies depending on the type of representational content (conceptual vs. perceptual). Encoding the same stimuli from different representational domains imposes varying memory loads in preschool-aged children. Developmental trends in WM for different types of content emerge between ages three and five. Findings provide insights for designing assessments tailored to young children's developmental and representational capacities.

Title: Research on mathematics anxiety in primary school: bibliometric analysis and evaluation of trends
Authors: Hilal Uğraş
Summary: This study aims to explore trends and key themes in research on mathematics anxiety in primary school students over a 45-year period. The findings indicate that research on mathematics anxiety in primary school has gained substantial attention in recent years, with an interdisciplinary nature involving both psychological and educational research. The results suggest a growing scholarly focus on the effects of mathematics anxiety, including how cognitive, emotional, and social factors contribute to its development and management. These findings underscore the need for continued integrated research in addressing mathematics anxiety at early educational stages.

Title: Epidemiological Investigation on the Clinical Status of the Developmental Dyslexia and ADHD Comorbidity among School-Age Children in Pakistan
Authors: Shujjah Haider; Tanmoy Mondal; Christopher A. Loffredo; Brent Korba; Irum Nawaz; Maleeha Azam; Tapas Sur; Somiranjan Ghosh
Summary: This study aimed to identify and confirm ADHD and developmental dyslexia among a sample of Pakistani school children, and explore the associations between these conditions and various risk factors. The researchers conducted a case-control study with 1,260 children aged 5-19 years, identifying 288 children with ADHD or dyslexia. Their findings revealed a significant gender difference in the cases, as well as differences in Vitamin D3 levels compared to the control group. The study suggests that other factors may influence the development of these neurodevelopmental disorders in the studied population.

Title: A Sunny Disposition and a Big Heart: Thematic Analysis of Parent-Reported Socio-Emotional Strengths in Dyslexia
Authors: Belinda Y. Zhang; Gabriela V. Gocheva; Ana Tyler; Amie Wallman-Jones; Marni Shabash; Jiwoo Han; Christa Watson-Pereira; Zachary A. Miller; Maria Luisa Gorno-Tempini; Virginia E. Sturm; Eleanor R. Palser
Summary: This study used a thematic analysis approach to identify five key socio-emotional strengths in children with dyslexia, as reported by their parents: social skills, positivity, reliability, determination, and creativity. The findings suggest that dyslexia may be associated with previously overlooked strengths that could be leveraged in remediation efforts to improve outcomes, reduce stigma, and foster resilience and self-esteem.

Title: The Effectiveness of Artificial Intelligence-Based Interventions for Students with Learning Disabilities: A Systematic Review
Authors: Andrea Paglialunga; Sergio Melogno
Summary: This systematic review aims to assess the efficacy of AI-based educational interventions for students with learning disabilities, with a focus on the methodological quality and risk of bias. The review found 11 studies representing 10 independent experiments with 3033 participants. The most studied disabilities were dyslexia and other specific learning disorders. Personalized/adaptive learning systems and game-based learning were the most common AI interventions. All 11 studies reported positive outcomes, but the risk of bias assessment revealed significant methodological limitations, with no studies rated as having a low risk of bias.

Title: Sex Differences in Stroke Risk Factors and Mechanisms in a Multi-Ethnic Asian Population
Authors: Narayanaswamy Venketasubramanian
Summary: This study investigated sex differences in stroke risk factors and mechanisms in a multi-ethnic Asian population. It found that compared to males, female stroke patients were older, had more diabetes mellitus, but less smoking, prior cerebrovascular events, and hemorrhagic stroke. However, there were no differences in ischemic stroke mechanisms or syndromes. The study also noted sex-ethnic differences, with more Chinese and fewer Indians among female stroke patients compared to males.

Title: Estimating a minimum clinically important difference for the Developmental Behaviour Checklist –parent report
Authors: Daniel L. Sutherland; Emma L. Taylor; Kylie M. Gray; Richard P. Hastings; Amanda Allard; Joanna Carr; Joanna Griffin; Nicola McMeekin; Elizabeth Randell; Daisy Russell; Bronwen Willoughby-Richards; Jeanne Wolstencroft; Paul A. Thompson
Summary: The study aimed to estimate a Minimum Clinically Important Difference (MCID) for the Developmental Behaviour Checklist, parent-report (DBC-P), which is a measure of behavioural and emotional problems in children and adolescents with intellectual disabilities. The researchers used distribution-based estimates through meta-analysis of intervention evaluations and anchor-based estimates using case scenarios with parent carers and professionals. The findings provide context for interpreting DBC-P score changes in relation to outcomes from other interventions and stakeholder views.

Title: Hidden Rhythms of a Developing Brain: Multimetric rs-fMRI Insights Into Typical Youth Maturation
Authors: Merida Galilea Tapia-Medina; Raquel Cosío-Guirado; Maribel Peró-Cebollero; Cristina Cañete-Massé; Erwin Rogelio Villuendas-González; Joan Guàrdia-Olmos
Summary: This study used resting-state fMRI to examine age-related changes in multiple functional metrics (fALFF, ReHo, VMHC) in a large sample of neurotypical youth aged 6-20 years. The results revealed a general pattern of declining local and interhemispheric connectivity with increasing age, indicating increased functional integration and network specialization during typical brain development from late childhood through adolescence. The combined use of these complementary metrics provides a robust framework for characterizing typical brain maturation and serves as a valuable benchmark for identifying developmental deviations in clinical populations.

Title: CAR-T cell therapy for glioblastoma: advances, challenges, and future directions
Authors: Wojciech Czyżewski; Klaudia Kus-Budzynska; Jan Sobstyl; Michał Sojka; Jakub Litak; Tomasz Szaliński; Mateusz P. Jeżewski; Michał Turek; Bipin Chaurasia; Tomasz Mandat; Kamil Torres; Grzegorz Staśkiewicz
Summary: This article examines the progress, effectiveness, and challenges of chimeric antigen receptor T (CAR-T) therapy for glioblastoma. It highlights the therapeutic potential of CAR-T cells, along with technological innovations aimed at enhancing their efficacy and safety. However, significant obstacles such as overcoming the blood-brain barrier and managing severe side effects remain.

Title: Brain Tumors, AI and Psychiatry: Predicting Tumor-Associated Psychiatric Syndromes with Machine Learning and Biomarkers
Authors: Matei Șerban; Corneliu Toader; Răzvan-Adrian Covache-Busuioc
Summary: This research paper explores the complex relationship between brain tumors and associated psychiatric disturbances. It discusses how brain tumors can lead to neuropsychiatric symptoms through various mechanisms, including metabolic reprogramming, neuroimmune activation, neurotransmitter dysregulation, and disruption of neural circuits. The article highlights the importance of early detection and precise diagnosis of these tumor-associated psychiatric syndromes, and proposes novel approaches such as lesion-network mapping, exosomal biomarkers, and AI-based predictive modeling to improve diagnosis and treatment. The paper emphasizes the need for a new paradigm in understanding and managing these conditions, as they are integral to the biology of the tumor rather than just secondary effects.

Title: Novel Association of the Presenilin-1 (Leu282Arg) Mutation with Isolated Spastic Paraparesis: Case Presentation and Review of Current Evidence
Authors: De la Sen-Domínguez, M.; Delgado-Alvarado, M.; Torres-Barquin, M.; Quirce, R.; Riancho, J.
Summary: This research article reports a case of a patient with a positive family history of early-onset Alzheimer's disease and cerebral amyloid angiopathy who presented with isolated spastic paraparesis. The authors reviewed previously published cases describing similar presentations related to Presenilin-1 mutations, highlighting the importance of considering these mutations in the differential diagnosis of patients presenting with spastic paraparesis, particularly in the presence of cognitive symptoms, cerebral amyloid angiopathy, or a family history of Alzheimer's disease.

Title: Visual enumeration remains challenging for multimodal generative AI
Authors: Alberto Testolin; Kuinan Hou; Marco Zorzi
Summary: This work proposes two benchmark tasks inspired by cognitive science to evaluate the visual enumeration capabilities of multimodal foundation models. The authors analyze popular visual question answering, image-to-text, and text-to-image AI systems and find that even the most advanced models cannot reliably name the number of objects in simple visual stimuli or generate images containing a target number of items, especially for numbers outside the subitizing range. The results demonstrate that developing an intuitive visual understanding of number remains challenging for AI models and that merely increasing model size might not be a viable strategy to promote the emergence of systematic counting skills.

Title: Functional specialization for language processing in inferior frontal regions during early childhood: evidence from functional near-infrared spectroscopy individual functional channels of interest approach
Authors: Haolun Luo; Tao Yu; Qun Li; Li Sheng
Summary: This study investigated the neural mechanisms underlying early language acquisition in toddlers using functional near-infrared spectroscopy. The results provide evidence for early neural specialization of language processing in the left inferior frontal gyrus, while revealing ongoing development in the right inferior frontal gyrus organization. The findings support models of early language-specific neural regions rather than gradual differentiation from domain-general mechanisms.

Title: Metabolic Factors Related to Interpersonal Dysfunction in Acromegaly: A Nationwide Cross-Sectional Study in China
Authors: Shashi Kiran Tagilapalli; Zongming Wang; Yuechu Lucinda Lu; Guofeng Zhang; Weijie Su; Zhentian Wu; Jiaming Wang; Qing Rao; Haijun Wang; Dongsheng He; Yonggao Mou; Shun Yao; Yanmei Tie; Wenli Chen
Summary: The study aimed to identify the clinical manifestations, metabolic factors, and comorbidities independently associated with interpersonal dysfunction in Chinese acromegaly patients. It found that physical disfigurement, palpitations, cardiac comorbidities, and elevated growth hormone levels were key predictors of high interpersonal dysfunction. The researchers suggest integrating psychosocial screening and referral to psychoneuroendocrine teams to mitigate social disability and improve quality of life in acromegaly patients.

Title: Relationship between polygenic risk scores for various psychiatric disorders and clinical and neuropsychological characteristics in children with attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder
Authors: WU Zhao-Min; WANG Peng; DONG Chao; CAO Xiao-Lan; HU Lan-Fang; KOU Cong; JIANG Jia-Jing; ZHANG Lin-Lin; YANG Li; WANG Yu-Feng; LI Ying; YANG Bin-Rang
Summary: This study investigated the relationship between the polygenic risks for various psychiatric disorders and clinical and neuropsychological characteristics in children with attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD). The results showed that children with ADHD had significantly higher polygenic risk scores (PRSs) for ADHD, major depressive disorder, anxiety disorder, and obsessive-compulsive disorder compared to healthy controls. The PRSs for various psychiatric disorders were also correlated with the behavioral and cognitive functions of children with ADHD, providing insights into the heterogeneity of ADHD.

Title: A Novel CHMP2B Splicing Variant in Atypical Presentation of Familial Frontotemporal Lobar Degeneration
Authors: Sara Rubio-Guerra; Sara Bernal; David Almenta; Josefina Pérez-Blanco; Valle Camacho; Isabel Sala; Mª Belén Sánchez-Saudinós; Jesús García Castro; Judit Selma-González; Miguel Ángel Santos-Santos; Álvaro Carbayo; Janina Turon-Sans; Ricard Rojas-Garcia; Daniel Alcolea; Juan Fortea; Alberto Lleó; Oriol Dols-Icardo; Ignacio Illán-Gala
Summary: This research article describes a novel splicing variant in the CHMP2B gene associated with frontotemporal lobar degeneration (FTLD) in a family from Spain. The cases involved two monozygotic twins with atypical presentations, including a behavioral variant of frontotemporal dementia and a syndrome mimicking dementia with Lewy bodies. The authors provide evidence supporting the pathogenicity of this variant and contribute new insights into the genetic landscape and clinical heterogeneity of FTLD.

Title: Musical rhythm abilities and risk for developmental speech-language problems and disorders: epidemiological and polygenic associations
Authors: Srishti Nayak; Enikő Ladányi; Else Eising; Yasminam Ekki; Rachana Nitin; Catherine T. Bush; Daniel E. Gustavson; Manuel Anglada-Tort; Hope S. Lancaster; Miriam A. Mosing; Fredrik Ullén; Cyrille L. Magne; Simon E. Fisher; Nori Jacoby; Reyna L. Gordon
Summary: The research investigates the association between musical rhythm abilities and developmental speech-language disorders. Findings suggest that non-linguistic rhythm impairment is a modest but consistent risk factor for developmental speech, language, and reading disorders. The study also finds shared genetic architecture between musical rhythm and reading abilities, suggesting genetic pleiotropy between musicality and language-related phenotypes.

Title: IQ variability and cognitive life skills: insights from Spanish students in vocational physical activity and sports training
Authors: María Madrid-Rísquez; Virginia Alcaraz-Rodríguez; Pilar Gómez-Rey; Antonio Muñoz-Llerena
Summary: This study aimed to analyze the development of four cognitive areas (verbal comprehension, perceptual reasoning, working memory, and processing speed) and the Full Scale Intellectual Quotient (FSIQ) in Spanish vocational students in the Intermediate Vocational Training Program in Outdoor Activity Guidance. The results revealed that students generally scored below the population mean in overall IQ, with significant variability. The study highlights the challenges faced by vocational students, particularly in areas critical for learning, and emphasizes the need for tailored educational support to enhance their cognitive performance and success in vocational education pathways.

Title: Developmental Language Disorder and Risk of Dyslexia—Can They Be Told Apart?
Authors: Aliki Chalikia; Asimina M. Ralli; Faye Antoniou
Summary: This study investigates differences and similarities among children with Developmental Language Disorder (DLD), children at Risk of Dyslexia (RfD), and typically developing children (TD) in phonological processing, verbal working memory, oral language, and word decoding. Both special groups (DLD, RfD) performed significantly worse than the TD group across nearly all measurements. DLD children showed pronounced oral language and verbal short-term memory deficits, while RfD children primarily struggled with decoding and explicit phonological awareness. The findings are discussed in light of the theoretical models of the relationship between DLD and Dyslexia.

Title: Developmental Coordination Disorder in Preschool-Aged Children: A Neuropsychological Perspective on Visuospatial Working Memory and Attentional, Planning, and Decision-Making Processing in Relation to Fundamental Movement Skills
Authors: Katerina Asonitou; Dimitra Koutsouki; Thomas Kourtessis; Antonis Kambas
Summary: This study investigates specific neuropsychological functions—visuospatial working memory, attention, planning, and decision-making—among preschool-aged children with Developmental Coordination Disorder (DCD) compared to typically developing peers. The findings highlight significant performance disparities between DCD and typically developing children across attentional and planning domains, with notable cognitive-motor correlations. The study suggests that targeted cognitive assessments can enhance early diagnosis and guide personalized motor-cognitive interventions to improve developmental outcomes in children with DCD.

Title: Dual Attention-Based recurrent neural network and Two-Tier optimization algorithm for human activity recognition in individuals with disabilities
Authors: Hend Khalid Alkahtani; Gouse Pasha Mohammed; Radwa Marzouk
Summary: This research proposes a Dual Attention-Based Two-Tier Metaheuristic Optimization Algorithm for Human Activity Recognition with Disabilities (DATTMOA-HARD) model. The main intention of the DATTMOA-HARD model is to improve human activity recognition (HAR) to assist disabled individuals. The model employs Z-score normalization, binary firefly algorithm for feature selection, dual attention bidirectional gated recurrent unit for classification, and Tasmanian devil optimizer for hyperparameter tuning. The DATTMOA-HARD approach achieved an accuracy of 98.66% on the HAR dataset, outperforming existing methods.

Title: Hemoglobin-to-red blood cell distribution width ratio in the relationship between occupational aluminum exposure and cognitive function impairment: a mediation analysis
Authors: Ruo-nan Wang; Zhuo-hui Wang; Wen-cheng Hu; Fan-peng Kong; Zi-yan Pei; Jing Song; Xiao-ting Lu; Bao-long Pan
Summary: This study investigated the partial mediating role of the inflammatory marker hemoglobin-to-red cell distribution width ratio (HRR) in the association between occupational aluminum exposure and cognitive function impairment. The results showed that occupational aluminum exposure negatively affects workers' cognitive function and HRR levels, and HRR can partially explain the effects of occupational aluminum exposure on workers' cognitive function.

Title: Breaking barriers: ten essential steps to achieve gender equality in academiathrough scienti ﬁc societies
Authors: Ana Genua-Olmedo; Sílvia Poblador; Judit Lecina-Diaz; María Mar Sánchez-Montoya; Pablo Rodríguez-Lozano; Mireia Bartrons; Elena Hernández-del Amo; María Anton-Pardo; Núria Catalán; Ada Pastor; Miguel Cañedo-Argüelles; Anna Freixa; Susana Bernal
Summary: The article discusses the persistent gender gap in STEM disciplines and proposes ten actionable steps for scientific societies to address this issue. It highlights the need to make invisible obstacles to gender equity visible and engage the entire STEM community in creating more inclusive and equitable academic environments.

Title: TOPSIS driven complex picture fuzzy approach for speech matching and sports training feature recognition
Authors: Walid Emam; Munazza Amin; Raiha Imran; Muhammad Safdar Nazeer; Kifayat Ullah; Zeeshan Ali
Summary: This research proposes incorporating complex picture fuzzy information measures (CPF-IM) to enhance the accuracy of TOPSIS-based decision-making for speech matching and sports training feature recognition. The study developed novel similarity measures (SMs) and distance measures (DMs) to handle real and imaginary components of complex picture fuzzy sets (CPFS). The results show the proposed CPF-TOPSIS approach outperforms other techniques in terms of accuracy and reliability, enabling better expert assessment decisions by effectively handling uncertain data, cyclical patterns, and evaluation hesitations.

Title: Children with and without reading difficulty value robot reading companions that are smart, supportive, and personalised
Authors: Ryssa Moffat; Hannah Cahill; Emily S. Cross; Nathan Caruana
Summary: The study explored children's expectations, needs, and desires for a robot that supports reading through co-design sessions and interviews. Key findings suggest that children designed robots that could deliver reading-specific support alongside emotional support, with important features including prosocial behaviors, breadth of knowledge, and customizable designs. The results have implications for the design and implementation of social robots to support reading, indicating that children are open to interacting with reading robot companions.

Title: Sarcopenic Obesity Defined by Japanese Working Group on Sarcopenic Obesity in Post-Stroke Inpatients: Prevalence and Clinical Implications
Authors: Ayaka Matsumoto; Yoshihiro Yoshimura; Hidetaka Wakabayashi; Fumihiko Nagano; Sayuri Shimazu; Yoshifumi Kido; Ai Shiraishi; Takenori Hamada; Kouki Yoneda; Takahiro Bise; Aomi Kuzuhara
Summary: This study investigated the prevalence of sarcopenic obesity (SO) as defined by the Japanese Working Group on Sarcopenic Obesity (JWGSO) criteria in post-stroke patients undergoing rehabilitation and its association with activities of daily living (ADL) and length of hospital stay. The study found that the prevalence of JWGSO-defined SO was 5.4%, with no significant association with ADL or length of stay. However, sarcopenia alone demonstrated significant negative associations with both outcomes, suggesting the importance of addressing muscle mass and strength in stroke rehabilitation.

Title: Pre-CBT resting-state connectivity and white matter integrity in OCD remission: A multimodal MRI study
Authors: Yuki Ikemizu; Yuko Isobe; Yusuke Sudo; Junko Ota; Ritu Bhusal Chhatkulia; Tubasa Sasaki; Kohei Kurita; Tokiko Yoshida; Koji Matsumoto; Masaru Kuno; Naoko Kato; Akiko Nakagawa; Eiji Shimizu; Yoshiyuki Hirano
Summary: This study investigates the relationship between pre-treatment functional and structural connectivity and remission status in OCD patients following cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT). The findings suggest that enhanced pre-treatment functional connectivity in visual processing regions and specific white matter tracts may serve as biomarkers for remission in OCD following CBT, potentially improving the understanding of CBT's neural effects and guiding personalized treatment strategies.

Title: Machine learning in the prediction of diabetic peripheral neuropathy: a systematic review
Authors: Yueying Ma; Zhiying Wang; Zheng Yao; Bin Lu; Yanming He
Summary: This systematic review provides an overview of machine learning (ML) methods for predicting diabetic peripheral neuropathy (DPN). The review found that existing DPN prediction models demonstrate good performance in discrimination, but the overall risk of bias in the included studies is high, and their applicability is limited. Future efforts should prioritize prospective, large, multicentre datasets, external validation, and adherence to PROBAST guidelines to reduce bias and enhance applicability for clinical application.

Title: Spatial distribution patterns and risk factors of hookworm disease in China: A study based on successive national surveillance
Authors: Huihui Zhu; Jilei Huang; Jinxin Zheng; Changhai Zhou; Tingjun Zhu; Mizhen Zhang; Luyuan Zhao; Xiaohong Wu; Jingbo Xue; Xiao-Nong Zhou; Shizhu Li; Menbao Qian
Summary: This study analyzes the spatial distribution patterns and risk factors of hookworm disease in China using data from national surveillance from 2016 to 2021. The researchers found significant geographic disparities, with the highest infection rates in south-western regions and the lowest in the Northeast. Key risk factors identified include the frequency of barefoot farming, land cover, average relative humidity, and average monthly sunshine duration.

Title: DiabetesXpertNet: An innovative attention-based CNN for accurate type 2 diabetes prediction
Authors: Rahman Farnoosh; Karlo Abnoosian; Rasha Abbas Isewid; Danial Javaheri
Summary: This study introduces DiabetesXpertNet, an innovative deep learning framework designed to enhance the prediction of Type 2 diabetes mellitus. DiabetesXpertNet incorporates a convolutional neural network architecture with dynamic channel attention modules to prioritize clinically significant features and a context-aware feature enhancer to capture complex sequential relationships within structured datasets. The model employs advanced preprocessing techniques and a logistic regression-based class weighting strategy to address challenges such as imbalanced datasets, high-dimensional data, missing values, and outliers. Evaluated on the PID and Frankfurt Hospital, Germany Diabetes datasets, DiabetesXpertNet achieves state-of-the-art performance in predicting Type 2 diabetes.

Title: Diverging roles of domain-specific anxieties in number-space associations. Insights from a multi-directional number line paradigm
Authors: Sophie J. Leonard; Flavia H. Santos
Summary: This study examines the impacts of math anxiety and spatial anxiety on visuo-spatial elements of mathematical performance, such as number line estimation. The researchers implemented three adaptations of the multi-directional number line task to simultaneously assess elements of individual differences in spatial-numerical associations. The results indicate that while directional number line estimation was predicted by math anxiety, no relationship was found for spatial anxiety in any of the three experiments. The study also explores the relationship between these emotional factors and gender.

Title: User cum expert judgement model for accessibility using fuzzy approach
Authors: Kumari Sarita; Parminder Kaur; Satinder Kaur
Summary: The study proposes a fuzzy-based model that combines user and expert evaluations to assess website accessibility. The model was applied to 20 websites from healthcare and incubation domains, involving users with low vision and experts. The results indicate that healthcare websites have better accessibility compared to incubation websites, though both need to address certain critical issues to achieve excellent accessibility. The proposed model can aggregate diverse user and expert responses to contribute to more inclusive digital environments and provide more accurate and context-sensitive accessibility evaluation.

Title: Development of a Web-Based Intervention to Support Primary Health Care Professionals in Digital Health Measurement: User-Centered Participatory Approach
Authors: Kristel Meijers; Esther Bols; Emmylou Beekman; Rachel Slangen; Peter Alexander van de Hoef; Darcy Ummels; Rik Crutzen
Summary: This research aimed to identify the most appropriate format and content for an intervention to support primary health care professionals in adopting digital health measurement. Using a participatory action research and user-centered design approach, the researchers developed a web-based, stepwise intervention that combines theoretical information, practical aids, examples, and experiences. The key features of the intervention include concise content, intuitive and attractive graphic design, and flexible navigation and functionalities. The iterative development process led to improvements in usability ratings.

Title: An investigation of the effects of different text formats on middle school students' reading comprehension performance
Authors: Betül Koparan
Summary: This study is a quasi-experimental research that aims to compare the reading comprehension levels of students who read texts in textbooks through printed, digital, and augmented reality (AR)-supported formats. The results showed that the AR-supported reading activity improved students' reading comprehension performance in all sub-dimensions of reading comprehension. These findings indicate that AR content is more effective in improving students' reading comprehension compared to printed and digital texts when reading storybooks.

Title: Effects of sedentary discontinuous intervention on physiological function and mental health of middle school students
Authors: Wanjun Li; Qiang Tang; Xingzhi Yan; Bingcai Yan
Summary: This study explores the effects of sedentary discontinuity on the physical and mental health of middle school students. The experimental group added 4 times of 5-8 minutes of physical exercise between classes every day, while the control group arranged the physical exercise between classes independently. The results show that the sedentary intermittent intervention can effectively improve the physical health level of adolescents and reduce the risk of cardiovascular disease. Schools should actively carry out physical exercise during recess to help students grow up healthily.

Title: Suicide risk, psychopathology and cognitive impairments in schizophrenia with insomnia: a large-scale cross-sectional study
Authors: Chenghao Lu; Dan Qi; Yunxuan Ping; Chuhao Zhang; Shuzhe Wang; Nannan Liu; Xinxu Wang; Shen Li; Jie Li
Summary: This study investigated the prevalence of suicide risk, clinical characteristics, and cognitive impairments in a large sample of chronic schizophrenia patients with insomnia. The results showed that chronic schizophrenia patients with insomnia have a higher risk of suicide, and that language function and general psychopathology serve as risk factors and predictors of suicide risk in this population.

Title: Artificial intelligence in drug development for delirium and Alzheimer's disease
Authors: Ruixue Ai; Xianglu Xiao; Shenglong Deng; Nan Yang; Xiaodan Xing; Leiv Otto Watne; Geir Selbæk; Yehani Wedatilake; Chenglong Xie; David C. Rubinsztein; Jennifer E. Palmer; Bjørn Erik Neerland; Hongming Chen; Zhangming Niu; Guang Yang; Evandro Fei Fang
Summary: This review explores the pivotal role of artificial intelligence (AI) in revolutionizing drug discovery for Alzheimer's disease (AD) and delirium from target identification to the development of small molecule and protein-based therapies. It highlights recent advances in deep learning, particularly in accurate protein structure prediction, which are facilitating novel approaches to drug design and expediting the discovery pipeline for biological and small molecule therapeutics. The review concludes with an appraisal of current achievements and limitations, and touches on prospects for the use of AI in advancing drug discovery in AD and delirium, emphasizing its transformative potential in addressing these two and possibly other neurodegenerative conditions.

Title: Transcranial Direct Current Stimulation in Parkinson's Disease Patients in the Off State: A Randomized Controlled Crossover Trial Examining the Effects on Pain With and Without the Influence of Dopaminergic Medication
Authors: Yeray González-Zamorano; Marcos Moreno-Verdú; Alexis Martínez-Benito; Josué Fernández-Carnero; Juan Pablo Romero
Summary: This study aimed to determine the effect of a single session of transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS) over the primary motor cortex (M1) followed by usual dopaminergic medication on perceived pain and pain processing characteristics in Parkinson's disease (PD) patients in the Off state. The results showed that one session of tDCS over M1 alleviated pain perception in PD patients in the Off state, but tDCS followed by dopaminergic medication intake did not yield additional benefits in pain processing, suggesting pathways different from dopaminergic ones in pain regulation in PD patients.

Title: Generational effects in Down syndrome: Enriched environment enhances functionality without reducing Alzheimer's disease risk
Authors: Lídia Vaqué-Alcázar; Laura Videla; Bessy Benejam; Laura Del Hoyo Soriano; Isabel Barroeta; Susana Fernandez; Íñigo Rodríguez-Baz; José Enrique Arriola-Infante; Javier Arranz; Lucía Maure Blesa; Aida Sanjuan-Hernández; Alejandra O. Morcillo-Nieto; Alexandre Bejanin; Eider M. Arenaza-Urquijo; Alberto Lleó; David Bartrés-Faz; Maria Carmona-Iragui; Juan Fortea
Summary: This study investigates generational changes in individuals with Down syndrome (DS), examining the effects on intellectual disability (ID), functionality, and cognition. The results indicate a shift towards a higher proportion of individuals with mild/moderate ID, greater intelligence, and increased autonomy. However, this was not accompanied by a delay in the age of Alzheimer's disease (AD) onset in the DS cohort or in the literature over the past 35 years. The findings highlight notable generational improvements in DS, but no effects on the age at AD dementia diagnosis.

Title: Exploring the Ethical Dimensions of Care Dependency in Older People: A Transpersonal View
Authors: Ana-María Porcel-Gálvez; Enrique-Octavio Iñiguez-Castro; Gloria Martínez-Lacovic; Regina Allande-Cussó
Summary: This study aims to refine the concept of care dependency in older adults through a transpersonal and culturally sensitive lens. The analysis identifies four defining attributes: loss of autonomy, erosion of identity and self-image, biographical rupture, and negative coping. Antecedents include physiological aging, chronic degenerative disease, cognitive decline, and psychosocial/cultural factors that constrain autonomy. Consequences extend beyond functional limitations, affecting emotional well-being and generating ethical and context-specific decisions. The proposed conceptual framework offers practical guidance for applying a transpersonal approach, prioritizing mutual presence, active listening, cultural attunement, and shared decision-making to preserve dignity, meaning, and connection in daily care.

Title: Predictors of e-cigarette usage among individuals with asthma and COPD
Authors: Tucker Rathe; Mario F. Perez; Felicia Tanu; Nkiruka C. Atuegwu; Eric M. Mortensen
Summary: The study examined factors associated with the use of e-cigarettes among individuals with asthma and COPD. Factors like being over 45 years old, experiencing wheezing, and attempting to quit or reduce cigarette smoking were associated with using e-cigarettes. However, being Hispanic and being worried about the health impacts of tobacco products reduced the likelihood of using e-cigarettes as a smoking cessation tool.

Title: Cryo-EM studies of amyloid-β fibrils from human and murine brains carrying the Uppsala APP mutation (Δ690–695)
Authors: Mara Zielinski; Fernanda S. Peralta Reyes; Lothar Gremer; Simon Sommerhage; María Pagnon de la Vega; Christine Röder; Thomas V. Heidler; Stina Syvänen; Dieter Willbold; Dag Sehlin; Martin Ingelsson; Gunnar F. Schröder
Summary: This study used cryo-electron microscopy to investigate the structure of amyloid-β fibrils with the Uppsala APP mutation from transgenic mouse brain tissue and a patient with the same mutation. The murine Aβ fibrils were found to be nearly identical to previously described human type II filaments, while the human Aβ fibrils closely resembled type I fibrils. The researchers also determined the structures of tau filaments from the human sample, which were identical to those found in sporadic Alzheimer's disease. Additionally, the study presented the structures of four different amyloid-β fibril polymorphs formed in vitro, which differed from the folds observed in the brain samples.

Title: Producing Child-Centered Interventions: Social Network Factors Related to the Quality of Professional Development for Teachers of Autistic Students
Authors: Elizabeth McGhee Hassrick; Jessica Suhrheinrich; Patricia Schetter; Allison Nahmias; Melina Melgarejo; Jennica Li; Jonas Ventimiglia; Yue Yu; Aubyn Stahmer
Summary: This study investigates how the social networks of professional development (PD) providers impact their performance in coaching teachers on implementing evidence-based practices (EBPs) for autistic students. The findings suggest that PD providers with more connections to autism EBP experts and resources to individualize their PD efforts report higher performance as teacher coaches.

Title: Psychotic-like Experiences in Adolescents Enriched for High-Risk for Developing Severe Mental Illness: Change over Two-Years and Association with Neural Reward Processing and Affective Symptoms
Authors: Xiaoying Dong; Tina Gupta; Gretchen Haas; Kristen L. Eckstrand; Jennifer S. Silk; Neal D. Ryan; Erika E. Forbes
Summary: This study examined the changes in psychotic-like experiences (PLEs) over two years and their association with clinical symptoms and neural reward function in adolescents at high-risk or low-risk for severe mental illness. The results showed that PLEs and distress increased over time, with the high-risk group showing a greater rise in PLEs. Heightened right ventral striatum neural activation and higher anxiety at baseline predicted more PLEs at 24 months, suggesting that heightened vigilance and sensitivity to external stimuli may be important precursors to the development of PLEs in adolescents.

Title: Modeling neuron-astrocyte interactions in neural networks using distributed simulation
Authors: Han-Jia Jiang; Jugoslava Aćimović; Tiina Manninen; Iiro Ahokainen; Jonas Stapmanns; Mikko Lehtimäki; Markus Diesmann; Sacha J. van Albada; Hans Ekkehard Plesser; Marja-Leena Linne
Summary: This study advances understanding of local interactions and self-organization of neuron-astrocyte networks and contributes to the broader investigation of their potential relationship with global activity regimes and overall brain function. The authors present a new model-building framework for neuron-astrocyte networks, introduce connectivity concepts for tripartite neuron-astrocyte interactions, design a scalable architecture capable of simulating networks with up to a million cells, and demonstrate how neuron-astrocyte interactions drive the emergence of synchronization in local neuronal groups.

Title: Application of machine learning models for predicting depression among older adults with non-communicable diseases in India
Authors: Kanchan Yadav; Dechenla Tshering Bhutia
Summary: The study evaluated eight supervised machine learning models to predict depression among older adults in India, using data from the Longitudinal Ageing Study in India (LASI). The random forest model outperformed other models, achieving an AUROC of 0.996 and an accuracy of 95.6%. Key predictors of depression included poor sleep, age, BMI, IADL limitations, socioeconomic status, religion, smoking, education, and physical inactivity. The findings demonstrate the utility of machine learning, particularly random forest, for scalable screening and policy-driven interventions in geriatric mental health.

Title: Preoperative electroacupuncture for prevention of postoperative delirium in older adults undergoing total knee arthroplasty: protocol for a multicenter randomized controlled trial
Authors: Yifen Zhuo; Jialin Yang; Xuezhen Shi; Huifen Lin; Xincheng Liao; Yusheng Yao; Lei Chen
Summary: This study investigates whether preoperative electroacupuncture prevents postoperative delirium in older adults undergoing total knee arthroplasty. It is a multicenter, randomized, double-blind, sham-controlled trial that will enroll 1460 participants aged 65-90 years. Participants will be randomly assigned to receive either active electroacupuncture or sham electroacupuncture. The primary outcome is delirium incidence within 72 hours after surgery, assessed using the Confusion Assessment Method.

Title: Diagnostics of diabetic retinopathy based on fundus photos using machine learning methods with advanced feature engineering algorithms
Authors: Michał Gandor; Filip Pałka; Wojciech Książek; Paweł Pławiak; Aleksandra Siedlecka; Tomasz Jeruzalski; Magdalena Olender-Skorek; Kamil Jonak; Robert Rejdak; Katarzyna Nowomiejska; Anna Matysik-Woźniak; Miguel Teus; Carolina Arruabarrena Sanchez; Marek Sylwestrzak
Summary: The research aimed to develop and validate a machine learning model for early diagnosis of diabetic retinopathy. The study analyzed 14,402 fundus photographs from patients, leveraging a large dataset to enhance the trustworthiness and validity of the findings. The researchers employed 46 unique methods for feature selection and extraction, utilizing techniques such as CLAHE, B-CosFire, and Hough transform. The most successful model, using the Random Forest algorithm combined with LBP and GLCM for feature extraction, reached an accuracy of 80.41%, F1-Score of 74.41%, and AUC of 0.80.

Title: Hierarchical attention enhanced deep learning achieves high precision motor imagery classification in brain computer interfaces
Authors: Zhen Chen; Ye Cao; Qiangqiang Fu; Liyang Hou
Summary: This study presents a novel attention-enhanced convolutional-recurrent deep learning framework for motor imagery classification in Brain-Computer Interfaces (BCIs). The proposed approach integrates spatial feature extraction, temporal dynamics modeling, and selective attention mechanisms to achieve state-of-the-art accuracy of 97.2477% on a custom four-class motor imagery dataset. The study highlights the critical role of attention mechanisms in capturing task-relevant neural patterns amidst the high-dimensional, non-stationary nature of EEG signals, demonstrating the potential of biomimetic computational architectures to enhance BCI reliability and applications in neurorehabilitation technologies.

Title: Hypertension control in resource-constrained settings: Bridging socioeconomic gaps with predictive insights
Authors: Md Abul Kalam Azad; Md Abu Sufian; Lujain Alsadder; Sadia Zaman; Wahiba Hamzi; Amira Ali; Md. Zakir Hossain; Boumediene Hamzi
Summary: The study examines the critical gaps in hypertension management, emphasizing the urgent need to address modifiable risk factors, tailor therapeutic regimens, and integrate socioeconomic considerations into public health frameworks. It advocates for scalable, data-driven interventions to bridge the hypertension care gap, thereby mitigating cardiovascular disease risks and enhancing health equity in underserved regions.

Title: Cognitive abilities and internet use among older adults in the CzechRepublic and Slovenia
Authors: Peter Seljak; Tomas Dosedel; Barbara Grintal; Zdenka Milić Kavčič; Jana Goriup; Voyko Kavčič
Summary: This cross-sectional study investigates the association between cognitive abilities and ICT use among older adults in the Czech Republic and Slovenia. The findings show that higher cognitive abilities are significantly associated with greater ICT use in both countries, even after excluding individuals with probable cognitive impairments. This association remains robust after controlling for age, education, gender, and living arrangements. The study highlights the importance of integrating cognitive health into digital inclusion strategies targeting older populations, particularly in aging societies where technological access is essential for social participation and well-being.

Title: Similarity in Early Life Stress Exposure Is Associated With Similarity in Neural Representations in Early Adulthood
Authors: Miro Ilomäki; Jallu Lindblom; Marjo Flykt; Mervi Vänskä; Raija-Leena Punamäki; Patrik Wikman
Summary: The study examined whether interindividual similarity in early life stress (ELS) exposure aligns with similarity in neural representations and behavioral task performance in early adulthood. The findings suggest that prospective ELS, but not retrospective ELS, is significantly associated with neural representational similarity across multiple cortical regions. The study highlights the systematic and chronic effects of more moderate ELS on brain development and emphasizes the value of prospective measurements and advanced similarity analyses in capturing the nuanced influences of ELS.

Title: Spontaneous Modulation of Standard EEG Frequency Bands During a Neurofeedback-Like Task
Authors: Jacob Maaz; Véronique Paban; Laurent Waroquier; Arnaud Rey
Summary: The study examines whether EEG frequency bands targeted by neurofeedback change spontaneously over time, are influenced by a continuously modified visual stimulus, and are affected by the frequency of stimulus modification. The results reveal a spontaneous increase in alpha power, an increase in theta power when exposed to a continuously modified visual stimulus, and an absence of changes in the studied EEG frequency bands when manipulating the stimulus modification frequency. These findings suggest that EEG changes observed during neurofeedback may be influenced by the task environment itself, rather than solely by successful EEG self-modulation.

Title: Heart Regeneration and Repair: Molecular Mechanism and Therapeutic Targets
Authors: Mingchuan Liu; Tingwei Peng; Rui Yu; Kexin Wang; Di Wang; Xiaojie Jia; Yan Zhang; Jianqiang Hu; Bingchao Qi; Yan Li
Summary: The review discusses the physiological and microenvironmental changes during cardiomyocyte development, the intrinsic and extrinsic molecular mechanisms regulating cardiomyocyte proliferation, and various approaches for promoting heart regeneration, including cell transplantation, pharmacological and genetic interventions, and bioengineering methods. The review aims to clarify important issues and advance research on heart regeneration and its clinical applications.

Title: Barriers, facilitators and solutions to equitable career progression for disabled doctors: an integrative review
Authors: Megan E L Brown; Bryan Burford; Gillian Vance
Summary: This integrative review synthesises international empirical and grey literature to identify the barriers, facilitators and potential solutions that shape the career progression of disabled resident doctors. It finds that structural ableism, inaccessible systems and stigma around disclosure are consistently identified as barriers, while mentorship, affirming supervisory relationships and identity-affirming networks act as facilitators. However, most initiatives remain unevaluated, and UK-specific evidence is limited.

Title: The decline in reading for pleasure over 53 years of the American Time Use Survey
Authors: Hessica R. Bose; Beigi Bi; Bill R. Jonze; Daisy Bancourt
Summary: The study examines the decline in reading for pleasure in the US over the past 53 years, finding marked declines in the proportion of individuals reading daily, with disparities across population groups. The findings demonstrate the need for more targeted strategies to increase opportunities for reading for pleasure.

Title: Unveiling the Determinants of Prehospital Delay in Patients With Acute Myocardial Infarction: A Cross-Sectional Study
Authors: Wenman Lv; Xin Jin; Yue Yang; Yinji Jin
Summary: This study aims to comprehend the current status of prehospital delay among patients with acute myocardial infarction. It analyzes the correlation between various factors and prehospital delay and explores the influencing factors. The study finds that pain level is a protective factor, while impaired decision-making and psychological distress are risk factors. It also emphasizes the importance of family support in reducing prehospital delays, which can guide the development of targeted interventions for acute myocardial infarction patients in China and similar populations.

Title: THE EFFECT OF ANESTHESIA ON POSTOPERATIVE COGNITIVE DYSFUNCTION
Authors: Miro Bilić; Martina Lukšić; Martina Miklić Bublić; Zrinka Orešković; Davor Mijatović; Vilena Vrbanović Mijatović
Summary: This study aimed to determine the incidence of postoperative cognitive dysfunction (POCD) after general or regional anesthesia and identify potential risk factors. The results showed that 42.2% of patients developed POCD the day after surgery. Risk factors included lower education level, previous COVID-19 infection, higher Charlson comorbidity index, and general anesthesia. Older age was also associated with poorer cognitive test results regardless of the type of anesthesia. These findings suggest that identifying patients at risk of POCD before surgery can help adjust anesthesia and postoperative care to mitigate cognitive impairment.

Title: Participation and Experiences in Extracurricular Activities for Children With Developmental Language Disorder and Their Peers
Authors: Callyn Farrell; Virginia Slaughter; Aisling Mulvihill
Summary: This study investigated whether participation and experiences differ for children aged 4-to 12-years with a developmental language disorder (DLD) compared to their typically language developing (TLD) peers in organized extracurricular social activities (OESAs). The results showed that parents of children with DLD reported engagement in a similar number of OESAs and for a similar length of time on a weekly basis compared to parents of TLD children. When evaluating factors that facilitated positive participation experiences, parents of children with DLD provided ratings mostly comparable to those of TLD parents. However, ability-related factors, such as communication, motor, and social skills, were more likely to influence the participation experience for children with DLD when they disengaged from an OESA.

Title: Cortical dysfunction and impulsivity in non-suicidal self-injury: a multimodal study using TMS-EEG and fNIRS
Authors: Bolin Tan; Chunnan Tong; Peng Xie; Linfei Shou; Yue Ning; Lirong Hu; Tianyi Yuan
Summary: This study aimed to investigate the cortical excitability differences between adolescents with NSSI and healthy controls using concurrent TMS-EEG and fNIRS. The results showed that the NSSI group exhibited significantly higher scores on both the ANSAQ and SIOSS compared to the healthy controls, and fNIRS results showed reduced prefrontal and temporal lobe activation in the NSSI group. TMS-EEG analysis indicated heightened P30 amplitudes in the left and right prefrontal cortex in the NSSI group, suggesting abnormal cortical excitability, particularly in the prefrontal regions, which may contribute to impulsive behaviors and cognitive control difficulties in adolescents with NSSI.

Title: Longitudinal associations between preschoolers' 24-h movement behaviors and development of self-regulation, executive function, vocabulary, and numeracy
Authors: Kristoffer Buene Vabø; Katrine Nyvoll Aadland; Anthony D. Okely; Caterina Pesce; Eivind Aadland
Summary: This study aimed to examine longitudinal associations between 24-h movement behaviors (physical activity, sedentary behavior, screen time, and sleep) and change in self-regulation, executive function, vocabulary, and numeracy in preschool children. The authors found no significant associations in the primary analyses, but subgroup analyses showed significant associations in girls for change in inhibition and self-regulation.

Title: Transfer between Reading Comprehension and Word-Problem Solving among Children with Learning Difficulty in Both Domains
Authors: Lynn S. Fuchs; Pamela M. Seethaler; Sonya K. Sterba; Douglas Fuchs; Laurie E. Cutting; Jeannette Mancilla-Martinez; BrittanyLee N. Martin; Daniel Espinas
Summary: This research examined the effects of single-domain text-structure interventions (reading comprehension or word-problem solving) on improving both reading comprehension and word-problem solving among second-grade children with comorbid learning difficulties in these two domains. The study found that both types of interventions led to significant gains in the target domain as well as cross-domain transfer effects, suggesting that word-problem solving can be considered a form of text comprehension.
